awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: The Roles of Inter-limb Jets and Body Angles in Metachronal Paddling
awd_abstract_narration:
Commercial underwater drones typically rely on a single propeller element. If this element were to fail, then the drone would be lost.  In contrast, the existence of multiple propulsion elements would permit continued use upon failure of a single propeller.  Natural aquatic organisms illustrate a unique opportunity to use multiple propulsion elements to generate small-scale jets.  Krill, shrimp, and crayfish, all use several pairs of limbs in highly coordinated motion to swim. The animal rhythmically oscillates its limbs from the tail-to-head at low velocity, with the timing of each pair delayed relative to its neighbors.  Nature?s design uses much less energy than our engineered underwater drones. Mechanical elements, such as gears and timing belts, could be used to cost effectively mimic nature?s design.  However, the underlying fluid dynamics of this metachronal (sequential) paddling is not well-understood. A limited number of studies have suggested limb morphology, the precision timing of the paddling sequence, and the generation of jets in the wake of the organism all contribute to this unique propulsion mechanism.  This research project examines how coordination of adjacent limbs interact with the flow past the body to generate propulsive jets in the wake. Uncovering the underlying fluid dynamic principles of metachronal paddling will enable scalability to engineered devices, allowing for efficient design of miniaturized, bio-inspired autonomous underwater drones. 

This research project examines how the coordinated motion of multiple oscillating paddles merge with large-scale flow past a submerged object to generate propulsive forces.  A combination of experiments with both live animals and robotic models will be used. Tomographic particle image velocimetry measurements of free-swimming aquatic organisms will be used to validate flow fields predicted by physical models. Self-propelled metachronal swimming robots will be used to examine the flow for individual and collective motion of the robots. Mechanical performance with respect to body angles, swimming speeds, and neighbor distances in individual and small groups of metachronal paddling robots will be examined. A primary project outcome will be the fluid dynamics mechanism by which aquatic organisms achieve large body speeds by paddling individual limbs at low velocity. The outcomes of this research will enable engineers to design and coordinate the motion of multiple propellers on engineered devices.  In addition, the research project trains undergraduate and graduate students to conduct interdisciplinary research in bioengineering.  Existing mechanisms at both institutions (NSF-funded Oklahoma Louis-Stokes Alliance for Minority Participation and Georgia Tech FOCUS program) are being used to recruit under-represented students for the project, and the researchers are participating in outreach activities to high school students and their teachers.
org_div_long_name: Division of Chemical, Bioengineering, Environmental, and Transport Systems

por.por_cntn:
Commercial underwater drones typically rely on a single propeller element for propulsion, putting these devices at risk for becoming irretrievable should the propellor become damaged while in use.  To address this problem, these devices should be re-designed such that propulsion is distributed between multiple elements, rather than one, so that motion can continue even when a single element fails.  Inspiration for an alternative design comes from aquatic organisms such as krill, shrimp, and crayfish who employ a strategy of propulsion known as metachrony, in which four or five pairs of limbs acting as paddles beat sequentially from the animal?s tail to head, resulting in a wave-like pattern that propels the organism. Metachronal propulsion is used across a large range of sizes and speeds in many underwater organisms, yet little is known about the underlying fluid dynamics principles that enable the robust scalability of this propulsion strategy. The important considerations include the balance of inertia effects compared to viscous effects, the ratio of which is the Reynolds number.  This research recorded live, free-swimming, animals in three dimensions using high-speed cameras to examine how small-scale fluid jets generated by the coordinated motion of oscillating paddles merge with large-scale flow past the body to generate propulsive forces.  Our measurements were shared with researchers at Oklahoma State University who fabricated robotic agents that employ many of the design elements observed in the live organism behavior.

For the first time, the propulsion and flow disturbance of a caridoid escape response performed by an Antarctic krill (Euphausia superba) has been quantified.  The caridoid response is an escape maneuver unique to crustaceans, where the animal rapidly bends its abdomen, bringing its head and tail together, resulting in a powerful stroke that propels the organism backwards.  This maneuver allows the animal to increase its speed by two orders of magnitude in a 0.025 second interval, reaching a maximum speed of 25 cm/s.  Antarctic krill typically swim in a low to intermediate Reynolds number regime where viscous forces are significant.  The high maneuverability when performing a caridoid response allows them to quickly change its body angle and swimming speed, overcoming these viscous forces.

Previous studies of metachronal swimming in crustaceans have focused on organisms whose limbs on the same abdominal segment beat in tandem with each other resulting in one, 5-paddle metachronal stroke. In contrast, for the mysid shrimp Americamysis bahia, limbs on the same abdominal segment beat independently of each other resulting in a metachronal stroke comprised of two, 5-paddle metachronal cycles running the length of the body that are 180? out-of-phase with each other.  By using more paddles in their metachronal stroke, mysids achieve faster normalized speeds while swimming more smoothly than krill.  Analysis of non-dimensional parameters indicate that mysid shrimp metachrony is tuned to achieve swim speeds greater than 9 body length per second.

The physical environment, characterized as Reynolds number, imposes an inertia versus viscosity balance constraint on propulsion across species, yet similar swimming modes, including upside down swimming, fast forward swimming, and hovering, arise among species at different Reynolds numbers. Reynolds number and swimming mode both influence the resulting stroke kinematics, but these two factors are typically studied in isolation.  As engineers begin to target metachrony for propulsive design, it becomes important to understand how Reynolds number and swimming mode interact.  Stroke kinematics for 5-paddle metachronal swimmers, including two euphausiid, three stomatopod, and one mysid species, were examined.  The results suggest that variations in metachronal stroke kinematics are more indicative of swimming mode than the flow regime, and the resulting swimming mode should be considered in computational and physical models of metachronal propulsion.

The project also had a strong educational and outreach effort.  This work brought together and provided training for two women pursuing Ph.D. degrees and 10 undergraduate researchers in STEM related fields, including engineering, biology, and ocean sciences.  Further, research results were presented to the scientific community and provided context for outreach efforts to educate the general public and students at local high schools.

 


Last Modified: 11/15/2021
Modified by: Donald R Webster
